newsitem.title: USA: New computer system saves NYC millions - official.
newsitem.headline: New computer system saves NYC millions - official.

text.p: A new computer and improved procedures at the Department of Finance helped the agency collect more than 1,500 percent more a year in unpaid taxes from city vendors, city Comptroller Alan Hevesi announced Tuesday.

In a follow-up audit by the comptroller's office, it was determined that the percent increase comes to an average of nearly $1 million a year more recouped by the department, compared to $55,000 collected under its old system, the comptroller said in a statement.

"Over the years, the city will collect millions more in unpaid taxes from vendors as a result of improvements made at the Department of Finance, which were spurred by a 1992 Comptroller's Office Audit," he said.
Each year the city pays hundreds of millions of dollars to vendors while, at the same time, trying to collect millions of dollars in back taxes from some of them.

The comptroller's audits recommended to the department, among other things, the use of computers. The follow-up audit sought to determine whether the recommendations from the prior review were addressed by the new system.
The audit found that all the recommendations have been implemented.
The Department of Finance collects about $11 billion annually in various city taxes, including real estate, general corporation, hotel occupancy and commercial rent taxes.
